section.name: Annotation quick reference guide
section.p: This quick reference guide documents the annotations used by genesis. This includes annotations for UI and server components. Examples provided with each tag come from useradmin sample application.

section.name: genesis Annotations
section.p: genesis annotations are classified by it's scope in:

ul.li: Class: use before a class definition
Atribute: use before an attribute getter
Method: use before a method definition

section.p: Some annotations are valid in more than one scope.

section.name: genesis JXPath auxiliary functions
section.p: genesis add these functions as extensions to JXPath:
These functions may be applied to all annotations that accept boolean JXPath expressions as parameters. The g: prefix defines the genesis namespace. Core JXPath functions don't use any prefix.

subsection.name: g:isEmpty(any), g:isNotEmpty(any)
subsection.p: Checks whether a field is empty or not.When the argument is a form property, the EmptyResolver instance configured for it is used to determine the return value. If the argument is a variable or a constant, a default EmptyResolver instance for the expression type is obtained from EmptyResolverRegistry and used for evaluation.

subsection.name: g:equals(any,any), g:notEquals(any,any)
subsection.p: Checks if a field value is equal to some constant or another field value. Uses any @EqualityComparator defined class available or a default implementation to make this decision. Accepts numbers, strings, fields or JXPath functions as arguments.

subsection.name: g:hasChanged(property), g:hasNotChanged(property)
subsection.p: Checks whether a field value has been changed or not. genesis internally keeps control of fields that have their value changed in the current iteraction using the EqualityComparator instance configured for the property.

subsection.name: @Form
subsection.p: Mark this class as a genesis form. genesis forms contain UI logic and are not coupled to the graphical API used to display screens. A form is just a JavaBean that has annotations that indicate how its properties and methods should be handled by a UI.
Example (InsertUpdateForm.java):
subsection.source: /** * @Form * @Condition findRoleCondition=g:isNotEmpty(roleCode) and g:hasChanged(roleCode) * * @struts.form */ public class InsertUpdateForm { ...

subsection.name: @Condition
subsection.p: Names conditionName as a condition variable that is exported in order to represent the expression jxpathExpression in other points in the code. As every other JXPath variable, when it's used on a expression its name should be preceeded by $ as in $conditionName.
This annotation may be used at class level, in an attribute getter or in a method annotated as @Action. Its scope will always be class-wide, no matter where it's declared.

tr.td: See also genesis JXPath auxiliary functions

subsection.name: @DataProvider
subsection.p: This annotation may be used in methods returning either a java.util.List or an array. Values returned by the method will be used to populate the combo or the table. objectField, if specified, should receive as a parameter the name of a property that will hold the instance selected on the widget. This property should be of the same type or a superclass of the type returned by the annotated method, an array of this type or a Collection. indexField is the property that will hold indexes for the selected elements on the widget. It must be an int or an Integer, an array of one of these types or a Collection. At least one of these two parameters must be informed.
The widget name is equal to the value specified for objectField or indexField. When both are specified, objectField value must be equal to the widget name.

subsection.name: @EnabledWhen
subsection.p: Enables a widget upon a certain condition (JXPath expression or @Condition variable) is true. This annotation may be used in attributes and actions.

subsection.p: Show or hide widgets as results from evaluating a boolean JXPath expression. Its syntax is similar to the one for @EnabledWhen and it also may be used to annotate attributes and actions.

subsection.p: Call the action when the boolean JXPath expression (or @Conditionvariable) evaluates to true. May be only used for actions (methods with @Action annotation) and not for attributes.

subsection.p: Cleans field content upon a true condition (JXPath boolean expression or @Condition variable). This annotation may only be used for attributes and not for actions (since actions do not have content).

subsection.name: @ValidateBefore
subsection.p: Support for validation in genesis is implemented by using one of Jakarta project's components, commons-validator.
Annotation @ValidateBefore may be used in actions that can only be executed when validation succeeds. May be only used for actions (methods with @Actionannotation) and not for attributes.

subsection.name: @EqualityComparator
subsection.p: Annotation may be used before form property getters. It identifies a class that knows how to compare form element of the same type. Its main parameter is the fully qualified class name (package.class) that implements the interface net.java.dev.genesis.equality.EqualityComparator. That class is internally used by g:equals(any,any) and g:notEquals(any,any) functions .

tr.td: Class name that implements the interface EqualityComparator.
A property name of the specified class
Attribute name of the class that implements the EqualityComparator interface. Might have many parameters of this type.

subsection.name: @EmptyResolver
subsection.p: Annotation may be used before form property getters. It identifies a class that knows how to compare elements of the same type. Its main parameter is the fully qualified class name (package.class) that implements the interface net.java.dev.genesis.resolvers.EmptyResolver. That class is used internally by g:isEmpty(any) and g:isNotEmpty(any) functions.

tr.td: Class name that implements the EmptyResolver interface.
Property name of the specified class
Property name of the class that implements EmptyResolver interface. Might have many parameters.

subsection.name: @EmptyValue
subsection.p: It specifies the empty value of a field. It's used together with the @ClearOn annotation.

tr.td: The value for an empty field

subsection.name: @Action
subsection.p: It defines a method as a target of the graphical interface binding. The action may represent a button and/or simply a method that is called whenever a condition is satisfied. The widget name has to be the same as the form method name in order to occur the dynamic binding.
Usage example (InsertUpdateForm.java):

subsection.name: @BeforeAction
subsection.p: It may be applied to a view method. Views are classes that extend one of the supported graphical interface classes. Currently, a view is a class that inherits the BaseThinlet class (or BaseDialogThinlet class). The @BeforeAction annotation applies to a view method that needs to be executed before the @Action annotated method. The method name must match the @Action name or this name must be indicated by an anonymous parameter.

tr.td: Name of the form method whose execution will be preceeded by this method execution
Only when the name of the view method does not match the form method name

subsection.name: @AfterAction
subsection.p: It may be applied to a view method. Views are classes that extend one of the supported graphical interface classes. Currently, a view is a class that inherits the BaseThinlet class (or BaseDialogThinlet class). The @AfterAction annotation applies to a view method that needs to be executed after the @Action annotated method. The method name must match the @Action name or this name must be indicated by an anonymous parameter.

tr.td: Name of the form method whose execution will be followed by this method execution
Only when the name of the view method does not match the form method name

subsection.name: @Remotable
subsection.p: It may be used to annotate business class methods. Methods annotated as @Remotable are intercepted by an aspect that transfers the instance in which the method has been invoked to the server, executing it there and returning the result back to the client. This feature is called transparent remoting.
Only concrete, non-static, non-native public methods can be annotated as @Remotable.

subsection.name: @Criteria
subsection.p: genesis support for Hibernate dynamic searches. This annotation implies the business method needs a Criteria instance in order to be executed, is also @Remotable, keeping the transparent remoting. Apply to public, concrete, non-static and non-native methods only.
